items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.20 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
		 
Article 9.20 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all Districts assigned service during the college semester for which the y are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.  
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.20 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.

Employee re-employed per the CSEA Chapter 363 CBA Article 22.2.1 "If the District reemploys a unit member as a permanent unit member under the provisions of this section, it shall disregard the break in service of the unit member and classify him/her as, and restore him/her to all the rights, benefits and burdens of a permanent unit member in the class to which he/she is reinstated."

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $83,400 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of August 10, 2013 through September 9, 2013 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts and Purchase Orders
items.item_text_raw: 9. Ratification of Contracts and Purchase Orders

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College participates in a regional partnership of educational institutions in Silicon Valley Counties to expand articulation efforts.  The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), effective July 1, 2013 through December 31, 2014, allows the college to receive funds in the amount of $19,576 to conduct activities identified in the MOU. 
	 
The West Valley-Mission Community College District serves as the fiscal agent.  Funding is contingent on SB 70 funding through the State of California.  Funding shall also be contingent on the West Valley-Mission Community College District receiving advanced apportionment from the State of California.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the MOU and accept grant funds in the amount of $19,576 from the West Valley-Mission Community College District.
items.item_text: MOU - Silicon Valley Stepping Stones Grant Partnership
items.item_text_raw: 10. MOU - Silicon Valley Stepping Stones Grant Partnership

items.item_details:
San Jose City College (SJCC) and Evergreen Valley College (EVC) will sign a Letter of Intent with the City College of San Francisco (CCSF).  The Letter of Intent states that the colleges will assist CCSF should the Accretiting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) decide to terminate CCSF's accreditation.  The Letter of Intent confirms the committment of SJCC and EVC to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) should CCSF transition to closing the campus to comply with ACCJC's termination plan. This MOU is in line with SJECCD's mission and vision and consistent with the policy adopted by the Board to support the success of every student.  
	 
The signed Letter of Intent from SJCC and EVC are attached.
items.item_recommendation: The Board approve the signing of a Letter of Intent to assist the City College of San Francisco should the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges decide to terminate CCSF's accreditation.
items.item_text: Letter of Intent to Support City College of San Francisco
items.item_text_raw: 11. Letter of Intent to Support City College of San Francisco

items.item_details:
Since 2005, Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Youth intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2013-14 program year.  Services include outreach, eligibility determination, assessment, job development/placement services, and follow-up services for youth ages 18-21 who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. Services will be delivered at the work2future Youth Training Center in San Jose and the South County One-Stop in Gilroy.
	 
Contract funding for the 2013-2014 Program Year is $509,706.00
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2013-2014 WIA Youth Contract in the amount of $509,706.00.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – 2013-2014 WIA work2future Youth Contract
items.item_text_raw: 12. Workforce Institute – 2013-2014 WIA work2future Youth Contract

items.item_details:
Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers at the Campbell, Gilroy, and San Jose One Stops. Workshops provided to job seekers help equip them with the skills they need to market themselves in this and future competitive job markets.
	 
work2future included Workforce Institute in its WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool\Eligible Training Provider List (ETPL) contract and has elected to make the contract a two-year contract beginning July 1, 2013 and ending June 30, 2015. For program year 2013-2014, work2future has awarded a NTE contract pool of $2,091,767 to each of its service providers. The overall contract dollars will be allocated to the various providers of instructor led workshops and online training as needed. Actual revenue earned through the WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool\Eligible Training Provider List (ETPL) is predicated on clients choosing Workforce Institute courses from a menu of workshops offered via the multiple providers. The 2013-2015 contract will be amended in the next program year to reflect the next year's funding, since funding allocation is on an annual basis.  Funding expectation is minimal.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2013-2015 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool\Eligible Training Provider List (ETPL) Contract in the amount of $5,000
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – 2013-2015 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool\Eligible Training Provider List (ETPL) Contract
items.item_text_raw: 13. Workforce Institute – 2013-2015 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool\Eligible Training Provider List (ETPL) Contract

items.item_details: Lana Strickland, full-time ESL professor at Evergreen Valley College, attended the Korea TESOL National Conference held at Korea University of Education in South Korea, May 25-26, 2013.  Key concepts of the conference included pedagogy, second language acquisition, theory informing practice and new technologies.  Attendance at this conference provided Professor Strickland an opportunity to grow professionally and learn current teaching practices and new technology to be used in the classroom.  In addition, Ms. Strickland received $500 in staff development funds to apply towards conference expenses.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees give retroactive approval for out of country travel to Professor Lana Strickland and approve funds in the amount of $500

items.item_text_raw: 16. Out of Country Travel

items.item_details:
Representing the Enlace STEM Project, four (4) students would be given the opportunity to attend the Hispanic Engineers National Conference in Indianapolis, Indiana, October 30 - November 3, 2013, and one (1) student to attend the SACNAS National Conference in San Antonio, Texas, October 3-6, 2013.  The following students will be accompanied by mathematics professor Cynthia Burnham: Francisco Estrada Vasquez, Edith Martinez, Mara Leandro, Javier Ramirez; and biology professor Al Gonzalez to accompany Rachel Vasquez.
	 
The benefits for the students would be multiple, including meeting professionals in their field; attending presentations and panel discussions; networking with other students, teachers and professionals; visiting exhibitors displaying the latest technology; and meeting recruiters.  The students will share their experience with other students via class presentations and reflections and pictures posted to the Enlace webpage on the EVC website.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve travel for Evergreen Valley College students to attend out-of-state conferences.

items.item_details:
On April 27, 2012, President Obama signed Executive Order 13607 establishing principles of excellence for educational institutions servicing service-members, veterans, spouses and other family members.  On August 9, 2013, Undersecretary of Education Martha Kanter and Allison Hickey, Under Secretary for Benefits, Department of Veteran Affairs, conducted a teleconference with leaders from community and four-year colleges nationwide.  Chancellor Cepeda was one of the participants in that conference call that resulted in the commitment to advance the premises of EO 13607 and to seek board approval for the initiative.  More than 250 community colleges and universities are committed to moving the initiative forward.  This item complies with that obligation and would commit the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College and the Workforce Institute) to the implementation of the "8 Keys to Success"  designed to:
	 
1. Create a culture of trust and connectedness across the campus community to promote wellbeing and success for Veterans
2. Ensure consistent and sustained support from campus leadership
3. Implement an early alert system to ensure all veterans received academic, career, and financial advice before challenges become overwhelming
4. Coordinate and centralize campus efforts for all veterans, together with the creation of a designated space (even if limited in size).
5. Collaborate with local communities and organizations, including government agencies, to align and coordinate various services for Veterans
6. Utilize a uniform set of data tools to collect and track information on Veterans, including demographics, retention and degree completions
7. Provide comprehensive professional development for faculty and staff on issues and challenges unique to veterans
8. Develop systems that ensure sustainability of effective practices for veterans
	 
Both colleges and the Workforce Institute have a long history of dedicated commitment to serve veterans.  This initiative would serve to further strengthen that commitment by establishing a framework for the systematic delivery of programs.
	 
Attached is the entire text of Executive Order 13607.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees support the implementation of the Veterans' Success Initiative; Executive Order 13607 Principles of Excellence and "8 Keys to Success"
items.item_text: Veterans' Success Initiative: Executive Order 13607 Principles of Excellence and "8 Keys to Success"
items.item_text_raw: 2. Veterans' Success Initiative: Executive Order 13607 Principles of Excellence and "8 Keys to Success"

items.item_details:
The Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges required EVC complete a Midterm Report with the requirement that the report be reviewed and approved by the BOT prior to its submission date of October 15, 2013.
	 
The college submitted Follow Up (Annual) Reports in 2011 and 2012.  In January 2013, the college was removed from warning status and its accreditation reaffirmed.  This year, 2013, is the regular midterm report year for EVC. This is the third year after the comprehensive evaluation conducted in 2010.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2013 Accreditation Midterm Report for Evergreen Valley College.

The college submitted Follow Up (Annual) Reports in 2011 and 2012.  In January 2013, the college was removed from probation status and its accreditation reaffirmed.  This year, 2013, is the regular midterm report year for SJCC. items.item_details:
The development of a "District Climate of Civility, Mutual Respect and Professionalism"  was one of the 2012-2013 Performance Objectives established for the Chancellor by the Board of Trustees. In response, the Chancellor prioritized the development of a statement on civility that would serve to respond to the Board's request, expand the conversation about civility to the District community, and comply with Accreditation Standard II.A.3.C, which states that institutions of higher education must ensure the 
	 
“Recognition of what it means to be an ethical human being and effective citizen:  qualities include an appreciation of ethical principles, civility and cultural interpersonal skills; respect for cultural diversity; historical and aesthetic sensitivity; and the willingness to assume civic, political, and social responsibilities locally, nationally and globally (Standard II.A.3.C.)”
	 
 A workplan was developed including some of the following key developmental and awareness activities: 
	 
Formation of the Civility Task Force – a districtwide invitation to serve was sent out and a significant number of individuals agreed to serve.  District Council members were also invited to serve. The Civility Task Force met on 11.7.2012; 12.5.2012; 2.6.2013; 3.6.2013; 4.10.2013; 5.1.2013; 8.7.2013; and 9.25.2013.  Agenda and meeting notes can be viewed at the following link:  http://www.sjeccd.edu/aboutus/chancellor/Pages/Chancellor.aspx   
	 
District Council consultation and review -   Drafts of the Civility Statement were shared and reviewed in several District Council meetings on:  12.20.2012; 2.21.2013; 3.21.2013; and 4.18.2013.
	 
Professional Development Day (PDD) Presentations –presentations designed to increase awareness and describe the work of the Civility Task Force were made at both colleges on the following dates:
January 25, 2013 - conducted a PPT presentation (Districtwide PDD held at SJCC) 
April 12, 2013 - including dissemination of draft statement
August 29, 2013 - including the beginning of an awareness campaign in conjunction with the college presidents including the dissemination wristlets imprinted with the words “Civility.Worth.Dignity," and the introduction of a slogan or brand for the District as follows:  “Civility begins with me! Everyone has Worth and Dignity.”  
	 
Attached is the final draft of the Civility Statement presented for Board adoption at the October 8, 2013 meeting.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopts the SJECCD Civility Statement.
items.item_text: SJECCD Civility Statement Adoption
items.item_text_raw: 5. SJECCD Civility Statement Adoption

items.item_details:
Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee. Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties.  The current CBOC convenes quarterly for meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee is required to have a minimum of seven (7) members comprised of one (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government, on the Committee and per the request of the District there be a minimum of one (1) Student representative per College, two (2) Community-At-Large members, one (1) Senior Citizens’ Organization member, one (1) Business Community member and one (1) Support Organization member. It is requested that the following applicants be appointed to the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee by the Board of Trustees to fill the current vacancies. 
	 
Member            Representing
Alex Ward         Student, San Jose City College                
Johnny Lee        Community-At-Large
	 
It is also requested that the Board of Trustees approves the request for current Community-At-Large member, Joseph Becker, to change affiliations for which he is representing on the Committee in order to fill the vacant seat of Senior Citizens’ Organization.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees appoint the following Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee applicants to fill the current vacancies on the committee.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Appointments
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Appointments

items.item_details:
On February 13, 2013 the board approved a Contract in the amount of $966,218 which consisted of removing and installing new roof, painting exterior building, repair parge coating and concrete as needed for Jaguar Gymnasium. 
	 
Upgrades and unforeseen conditions included:
- Upgrade (Paint exterior doors new color, paint interior and exterior window louvers)
- Upgrade (Refinish gym floor and paint new tick marks on gym floor)
- Unforeseen (Roof deck repair)
- Unforeseen (Roof framing repair)
- Unforeseen (Concrete parge coat repair) 
- Unforeseen (Concrete repair)
- Unforeseen (Removal and reinstall of gym floor protection due to campus event)
	 
Change Order No. 001 includes costs associated with the above items and deduction of remaining allowance funds from the contract.  This change was negotiated for a deductive cost of ($183,745) for a revised contract value of $782,473.  This final Change Order represents a total Change Order percentage of negative 3% against the original contract.
	 
Original Contract Amount      $  966,218
Previous Change Order(s)       $              0
Change Order No. 001           $(183,745)   
	 
Revised Contract Amount      $  782,473
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order 001 in the deductive amount of ($183,745) to Waterproofing Associates, Inc. for Jaguar Gym Roof Replacement Project at San Jose City College.

items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Change Order 001 Waterproofing Associates, Inc. – Jaguar Gym Roof Replacement Project at San Jose City College

items.item_details:
A year ago Evergreen Valley College began a campus-wide landscape assessment, planning and programming effort.  The intent was to perform a rigorous physical assessment of the site to fully understand the existing conditions and site concerns facing the campus.  Through this assessment the College was able to prioritize the improvements to be addressed.  One of these priority projects involves redesign of the drop-off area and plaza at the EVC Center for the Arts, and the redirection of the VTA bus access to campus.  This development is consistent with the EVC 2025 Facilities Master Plan.
	 
An RFQ was issued to the four landscape firms previously approved by the Board (August 14, 2012) for landscape design services (previous “pool” evaluations).  Three firms responded.  Each RFQ response was reviewed by a committee of District and EVC representatives, which then held interviews with each firm.  Based on the RFQ responses and the interviews, the committee has recommended that Bellinger Foster Steinmetz be awarded a contract in in the amount of $201,250 to provide landscape architecture services for the Center for Arts Plaza and Drop-off project at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment EVC-03 with Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture in the amount of $201,250 for design services related to Center for Arts Plaza and Drop-off at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) EVC-03 Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture design services for Center for Arts Plaza and Drop-off
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) EVC-03 Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture design services for Center for Arts Plaza and Drop-off

items.item_details:
A year ago Evergreen Valley College began a campus-wide landscape assessment, planning and programming effort.  The intent was to perform a rigorous physical assessment of the site to fully understand the existing conditions and site concerns facing the campus. Through this assessment the College was able to prioritize the improvements to be addressed.  One of these priority projects is development of the center area of campus that used to host temporary portable classrooms.  This area, known as the Center Green, will be the core gathering place on campus.  This development is consistent with the EVC 2025 Facilities Master Plan.
	 
An RFQ was issued to the four landscape firms previously approved by the Board (August 14, 2012) for landscape design services (previous âpoolâ evaluations).  All four firms responded.  Each RFQ response was reviewed by a committee of District and EVC representatives, which then held interviews with each firm.  Based on the RFQ responses and the interviews, the committee has recommended that Bellinger Foster Steinmetz be awarded a contract in in the amount of $226,750 to provide landscape architecture services for the Central Campus Site Improvement project at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of Project Assignment Amendment EVC-02 to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architecture in the amount of $226,750 for design services related to Central Campus Site Improvement project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On May 14, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Swenson & Associates to provide construction services to renovate and upgrade the Central Plant and Police Station at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Swenson & Associates submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include additional or deleted materials, equipment, labor, time extensions as applicable and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The six items in this change order total and add to the contract an amount of $23,956.
	 
Original Contract Amount            $9,965,000
Previous Approved Changes             $17,192
Change Order #002                           $23,956
Total Contract and Changes       $10,006,148
The net change to Swenson & Associatesâ contract as a result of all changes issued will be $41,148, which equates to 0.41% of the base contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order #002 for Swenson & Associates in the amount of $23,956 for the Evergreen Valley College Central Plant and Police Station Renovation Project.

items.item_details:
On July 9, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with JKL Construction Services, Inc. to provide construction services to upgrade and extend underground utilities including power, telecommunications, gas, heating and cooling water to buildings on campus.
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  During excavation several unforeseen conditions and unmarked utilities were encountered which required revisions to the design drawings. In addition, the contractor uncovered existing utilities that were leaking and required repair.  JKL has submitted change proposals, which were reviewed for accuracy and conformance with the Contract Documents.
	 
Original Contract Amount              $2,880,567
Previous Approved Changes         $0
Change Order No. 001                   $16,453    
	 
Total Contract and Changes           $2,897,020
	 
The total Change Order percentage for this project, including this change, represents .57% of the original contract.

On July 9, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Preston Pipelines, Inc. to provide construction services to repair and replace aged water mains on the San Jose City College campus. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Preston Pipelines submitted a written pricing proposal for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that includes materials, labor, and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms. This change represents the final closeout of their Contract.
	 
This change order represents an add to the contract of $6,850.

items.item_details:
On June 12, 2012 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with O.C. Jones & Sons, Inc. to replace the artificial field turf and the scoreboard at the San Jose City College Football stadium.  The turf was replaced during the summer of 2012, but after the start of construction, it was discovered that the existing football scoreboard had not been certified by DSA when it was constructed in 1992.  Between September 2012 and June 2013, design consultants and Gilbane worked with DSA to resolve outstanding issues and certified the existing scoreboard structure, which allowed the new scoreboard to be installed on the existing structure.  The new scoreboard is now complete and is in the process of full DSA closeout and certification. 
	 
This change is the result of additional underground conduit not shown on the contract drawings being required to connect the new scoreboard to the stadium press box, and a no-cost extension of time to the contractor for the delay associated with the College obtaining DSA approval for the existing scoreboard structure.  This Change represents full and final resolution of changes to O.C. Jonesâ contract for the project.
	 
Original Contract Amount              $797,850
Previous Approved Changes         ($27,596) credit
Change Order No. 001                   $3,179      
	 
Total Contract and Changes               $773,433
The total Change Order percentage for this project including this change represents negative 3.1% against the original contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 for O.C. Jones & Sons Inc. in the amount of $3,179 for the San Jose City College Track & Field Replacement Project.

The District issued a Request For Proposal (RFP) to prequalified design-build entities and received proposals from three firms.  The selection committee consisted of representatives of the District and a principal from HMC Architects.  The respondentsâ Proposals were reviewed against the requirements set forth in the RFP and ranked according to a point value system assigned to each of five categories.  The committee selected XL Construction / Des Architects as the Design Build Entity for this project, who achieved the highest ranking of 91.1 points, representing the best overall scores awarded for price, technical expertise, safety record, management plan and interviews.
	 
The contract value is $6,100,000

items.item_details: Each year, the Workforce Institute provides the Board of Trustees with an update of the previous yearâs activities.  The presentation identifies the federal, state, and local priorities as well as market drivers which helped to guide efforts throughout the 2012-2013 fiscal year.  The presentation will also identify Workforce Instituteâs specific programs, services, and/or responses to these priorities and drivers.  Highlights include the various grants awarded and/or implemented, corporate contracts awarded, job readiness services provided to unemployed or underemployed adults and at-risk youth, and ways in which Workforce Institute made non-program specific contributions to the district.

items.item_details:
Staff will review the results of the 2013 Student Success Scorecard for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College.  The Scorecard measures the success of students by tracking their progress along the pathway to completion of degrees, certificates, and transfer.  The outcomes tracked by the Student Success Scorecard are:
	 
Student Progress & Achievement Rate
Persistence Rate
30 Unit Achievement Rate
Basic Skills & ESL Progression Rate
Career & Technical Education Completion Rate
	 
	 
Each year, the California Community College Chancellor's Office will report on the status of these outcomes as a part of the State Chancellor's accountability reporting to the Governor.  The results for each are made public the results are can be used for comparison purposes.  Each college is required to share these data with the local Board of Trustees and inform the State Chancellor's office of the date of that report.
items.item_text: California Community Colleges Student Success Scorecard -- Required Board Information
items.item_text_raw: 2. California Community Colleges Student Success Scorecard -- Required Board Information

items.item_details:
Consonant with our 20% annual review process of board policies, Chapter 6 (District Business and Fiscal Services) is presented as a "first-read" to the Board.  It was presented to District Council on April 18, 2013 as a "first read" and for their dissemination to constituent groups and as a "second read" on September 16, 2013 for final input and suggestions.  
	 
The attached document contains three columns with titles at the top of each for the reader's comparison between CCLC (Community College League of California) recommended language,  language changes and the last column which represents final district recommended language to update Chapter 6 as presented and reviewed twice by District Council representatives)

items.item_details:
On July 9, 2013 the Board adopted Resolution #70913-2 Lease-Leaseback delivery method for the Physical Education/Gym Project #122.
	 
While under short-term contract with the District, Gilbane has been working to restart the project and clearly establish the path forward.  This presentation is to inform the Board of the current status of the project and the planned schedule to its successful completion.

items.item_details:
This report represents the status of schedule and cost for Measure G-2010 projects from inception through September 30, 2013, with financial data reconciled through June 30, 2013.
	 
#31121 (Photo Lab Relocation) - We are anticipating completion of the project approximately 4-5 weeks late, the first week of October.  We are working with College faculty and staff to ensure that students know where to go on the first day of class and to determine the best time for the program to move into the new space once it is complete.
	 
The three projects below cannot start and/or complete until the New Gym, a Measure G 2004 project, is complete.  Delays in the New Gym project have pushed it to the point where it is now impacting the start and/or completion of the three projects below.
	 
#31110 Utility Extension for New & Existing Buildings
#31114 Aux Gym, Pool & Locker Room Demo
#31116 Campus Site Improvements
